body:
Note: This would technically be a breaking change and would fall into [Bucket 3: Unlikely Grey Area](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/dev-process/breaking-change-contract.md#bucket-3-unlikely-grey-area).

In the context of the **file-system provider and the registry provider**:

`Move-Item -Force` allows you to replace an existing target file / target registry key (as does `New-Item`).

By contrast, **`Rename-Item -Force` currently refuses to replace (overwrite) an existing item**.

By contrast, all other providers that ship with PowerShell DO support replacing an existing target item via `Rename-Item -Force`:

* Function provider
* Alias provider
* Environment-variable provider
* Variable provider

(Note that these providers have non-hierarchical stores (flat list of items), so they only support `Rename-Item`, not also `Move-Item`).

Note: The forced replacement should only apply to _files_, not _directories_.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

From a filesystem location:

```powershell
New-Item t1, t2
Rename-Item -Force t1 t2
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

The command should (quietly) succeed in renaming `t1`  to `t2`, replacing the existing `t2`.

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
Rename-Item : The file '/Users/jdoe/t2' already exists.
```

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on macOS 10.13.3
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
Windows PowerShell v5.1.15063.674 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
```

body:
In Unix we have:

```
curl -O https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/archive/master.zip

# and

wget https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/archive/master.zip
```

which download the file called master.zip at PWD.

In PowerShell, we have to specify the filename:

```
curl -O master.zip https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/archive/master.zip
```

and prints the contents to stdout without -OutFile (or -O, -Ou, -Out, -OutF, -OutFi, -OutFil).

Sometimes target URL is read from resources other than manual input and file names are long, less human readable, and we are supposed to preserve the filenames. That requires extra processing / string manipulation cost, which is bit of an inconvenience.

Please add a shorthand `-Save` switch to make it less wordy, so we can do:


```
iwr -Save https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/archive/master.zip
```

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

body: Hi All, We are connecting our windows machine from the centos 7.3 using WINRM and Negotiate authentication. To do this, below packages have installed on the centos 7.3 1)powershell-6.1.0.preview.1-1.rhel.7.x86_64.rpm 2)omi-1.4.2-1.x86_64 3)gssntlmssp-0.7.0-1.el7.x86_64 pwsh session hangs when i am running two sequential invoke-command. invoke-command -computername IP-credential domain\user-authentication Negotiate -scriptblock {$pwd} Give the password. and able to get pwd details. but next if i run the same steps. powershell hang and waiting for nothing. I have tried this behavior from powershell-6.0.0_beta.6-1.el7.x86_64.rpm to till powershell-6.1.0.preview.1-1.rhel.7.x86_64.rpm. This behavior introduced in powershell-6.0.0_rc-1.rhel.7.x86_64.rpm where is its working fine powershell-6.0.0_beta.9-1 build. Also I am facing second issue. Till beta 6.0.0_beta.9-1 build the responses were very fast from windows to linux and vice versa but after RC and till latest build of power shell, It taking much time to connect to the system. in terms of data, where Beta was taking 6-10 sec to connect to system, the latest build is taking 1-2 minutes to connect the system. from beta to RC. i am not seeing much about remoting commit apart from inclusion of psrp packages. P.S: Separate Install-PowerShellRemoting.ps1 from psrp.windows nuget package. Can anybody help me to understand more about the issue like why it got introduced in RC where as in beta its was working fine and taking less time. Steps to reproduce ------------------ Expected behavior ----------------- Powershell should not hang second time and should get current directory result. Actual behavior --------------- powershell session should not hang for indefinite time. Root cause: While doing the root cause analysis through wireshark, we observed that during first time, handshaking is happening proper way[windows box is able to connect from linux]. but while doing second time connection, linux system is waiting for response. Environment data ---------------- > $PSVersionTable PSVersion 6.1.0-preview.1 PSEdition Core GitCommitId v6.1.0-preview.1 OS Linux 3.10.0-693.21.1.el7.x86_64 #1 SMP Wed Mar 7 19:03:37 UTC 2018 Platform Unix PSCompatibleVersions {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...} PSRemotingProtocolVersion 2.3 SerializationVersion 1.1.0.1 WSManStackVersion 3.0

body:
Not my idea, but had a conversation with someone last week (and asked him to open an issue...).

He has many situations where cmdlets have a number of common parameters and then each has one or two of its own. So what he'd like to do is:

```powershell
$commonParameters = @{
    Foo = "Duck"
    Bar = "Moo"
}

Start-FirstThing <splat-syntax>$commonParameters + @{ Arg = 6 }</splat-syntax>

Start-SecondThing <splat-syntax>$commonParameters + @{ Quux = "Bang" }</splat-syntax>
```

Now, I know there are a bunch of ways to come close to this and a few workarounds. **But**, I personally like the sentiment that *expressions* should be splattable, rather than *variables*.

body:
_[Updated based on @lzybkr's feedback below.]_

Use of `[CmdletBinding()]` and parameter attributes in `Filter` functions requires special considerations, and it is easy to create functions that invariably fail at runtime, in obscure fashion.

Perhaps it's possible to detect such cases at parse time.

Note that a tempting reason to use `[CmdletBinding()]` is to benefit from its automatic enforcement of allowing only arguments for explicitly declared parameters to be passed.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
Filter foo1 { [CmdletBinding()] param() $_ }
Filter foo2 { param([Parameter(Position=0)] $Bar) $_ }
1 | foo1; 1 | foo2
```

The reasons these two `Filter` functions invariably fail when invoked is that - due to using `[CmdletBinding()]` and/or parameter attributes - at least one pipeline-binding parameter must be defined explicitly.  
This requirement makes the use of these attributes in `Filter` functions impractical, as you may as well define a regular `Function` function with an explicit `process` block at that point, which offers the added flexibility of `begin` and `end` blocks.

Expected behavior
-----------------

Ideally, report an error during the parsing stage.

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
foo1 : The input object cannot be bound to any parameters for the command either 
because the command does not take pipeline input or the input and its properties 
do not match any of the parameters that take pipeline input.
...
foo2 : The input object cannot be bound to any parameters for the command either 
because the command does not take pipeline input or the input and its properties 
do not match any of the parameters that take pipeline input.
```

That is, the function definitions succeeded, but any attempt to use them invariably fails.

Note that if you use just `[CmdletBinding()]`  and no `param()` block, the functions don't break, but `[CmdletBinding()]` is quietly ignored.



Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on macOS 10.13.3
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
Windows PowerShell v5.1.15063.674 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
```

body:
<sup>On a side note: The automatic `$Is*` variables aren't universally loved due to "polluting" the global namespace, but it looks like they're here to stay.</sup>

Platforms with Unix heritage have many commonalities, especially at higher levels of abstraction, so **sometimes it is sufficient to distinguish Unix platforms _as a group_ from Windows**.

Thus, **instead of having to use `$IsLinux -or $IsMacOS` or `$PSVersionTable.Platform -eq 'Unix'`** (yes, [`Unix` is reported on both macOS and Linux](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/6513#issuecomment-376679563)), it **would be convenient to be able to say `$IsUnix`**.

_Update to clarify_: The variable `$IsUnix` would not be for everyone: Its target audience are developers who need to develop portable-across-Unix-like-systems-but-not-Windows functionality.

---

Note that the commonalities are reflected even at a lower level, namely in the [CoreFX](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx) implementation: as of this writing, among the Unix-related classes, 50 are abstract (`*.Unix.cs`), 25 are macOS-specific (`*.OSX.cs`), and 11 Linux-specific (`*.Linux.cs`)

Environment data
----------------

Written as of:

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2
```

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

title: Consider introducing $IsUnix as an abstraction over $IsMacOS and $IsLinux

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
help about_profile
```
`q` to exit.

Then immediately do it again.
```powershell
help about_profile
```

Expected behavior
-----------------
On 5.1, the first `q` exits the screen at the bottom. The text of the help is still on-screen, but the cursor and the input line are on the last line of the screen.
The second `help` (and anything else you might do) displays normally, scrolling or clearing the screen contents before displaying.

Actual behavior
---------------
On pwsh, the first `q` exits the screen at the top. The text of the help is still on-screen, but the cursor and the input line are the first line of the screen. This means that the output of anything else you do going forward gets mixed in with the help text that is left on-screen.

The second `help` doesn't clear the screen before it paints the text, resulting in garbled text. Here are a few lines from the top of the screen after the second `help`:

```powershell


ABOUT PROFILES
    Searching Help for about_profile ...
    [                                                                                                                        ]
SHORT DESCRIPTION
Describes how to create and use a PowerShell profile.
Describes how to create and use a PowerShell profile.

LONG DESCRIPTION
LONG DESCRIPTION
You can create a PowerShell profile to customize your environment and to
You can create a PowerShell profile to customize your environment and to.
add session-specific elements to every PowerShell session that you start.
A PowerShell profile is a script that runs when PowerShell starts. You can
A PowerShell profile is a script that runs when PowerShell starts. You cand
```

(To be clear, this is a screen handling issue, not a help or about_profile issue.)

Environment data
----------------

I did not load any profiles in either environment (5.1 or 6.x) for the purposes of this test. Both environments were started fresh, and I did not load any modules, etc. The "help about_profile" were the first commands I issued in both sessions.

body:
The PSv4+ collection operators `.Where()` and `.ForEach()` differ from normal pipeline-output collecting behavior in two respects:

* If the result is a _single_ item, it _isn't unwrapped_; that is, a _collection_ is _always_ returned, and
* that collection is always of type `[System.Collections.ObjectModel.Collection[psobject]]` rather than a regular PS array (`[object[]]`)

In the spirit of https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-RFC/pull/120, the **behavior should be harmonized with how pipeline output is already collected and how the `-*Variable` common parameters (except `-PipelineVariable`) _should_ collect output, according to the RFC**.

Given how contentious the linked `-OutVariable`-related RFC is turning out to be, this proposal may need to become an RFC as well, though perhaps the decision on said RFC will imply how to proceed here.

To reiterate what, to me, motivates this desire for harmonization / resolving inconsistencies:

**The unifying vision is to provide a consistent experience whenever PowerShell collects output for you**, so you never need to worry about different unwrapping  behavior and/or differing collection types.

Note:

**This harmonization would currently incur a performance cost**, because the internally used, resizable collection data types must on output be converted to `object[]]`.

However, **the proper way to resolve this is to switch PowerShell's fundamental collection data type from `[object[]]` to an _efficiently resizable_ one that can be used internally _and_ directly output.**
[Discussion in that direction has started](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/5643#issuecomment-349811857), but it's obviously a massive _internal_ change; _externally_, assuming no bugs have crept in, however, much of existing code may not only continue to work as-is, but may exhibit automatic performance gains.

To quote @lzybkr  from the linked issue:

> I've often wondered if the comma operator could create a list instead of an array. I have a feeling most scripts would never notice a difference because of how freely things are converted to an object array.

Current Behavior
-----------------

```powershell
PS> (1).ForEach({$_}).GetType().Name; (1, 2).ForEach({$_}).GetType().Name
Collection`1  # single-item result wasn't unwrapped
Collection`1  # output collection type is not [object[]]
```

Desired Behavior
-----------------

```powershell
PS> (1).ForEach({$_}).GetType().Name; (1, 2).ForEach({$_}).GetType().Name
Int32      # single-item result was unwrapped
Object[]   # regular PS array
```

labels.description: The reported behavior is by design.
labels.name: Resolution-By Design

title: Collection operators .Where() and .ForEach() do not unwrap single-item results

body:
_Update_: @kvprasoon  suggests more generally to **support property _paths_ in cmdlets that accept property _names_**, typically via parameter `-Property`, such as `Select-Object` and  `Compare-Object`.

PSv3 introduced two simplified syntax forms that, in simple scenarios, allow use of _parameters_ (i.e., argument mode) rather than _script blocks_ for a cleaner, less "noisy" experience:

_Operation statements_ for `ForEach-Object`:

```powershell
# Equivalent to: ... | ForEach-Object { $_.one }
[pscustomobject] @{ one = 1 } | ForEach-Object one  # -> 1

# Equivalent to: 1 | ForEach-Object { $_.Equals(1) }
1 | ForEach-Object Equals 1    # -> $True
```

_Comparison statements_ for `Where-Object`:

```powershell
# Equivalent to: ... | Where-Object { $_.one -eq 1 }
[pscustomobject] @{ one = 1 } | Where-Object one -eq 1
```

However, the simplified syntax does'nt work for _nested_ member access, e.g., for accessing `one.two` in `[pscustomobject] @{ one = [pscustomobject] @{ two = 2 } }` - see below.

Note that, by contrast, analogous nested access _does_ work in general in "naked" expression-based arguments:

```powershell
$obj = [pscustomobject] @{ one = [pscustomobject] @{ two = 2 } }
Write-Output $obj.one.two  # correctly yields 2
```

Therefore, nested instance-member access - both properties and methods - should be supported.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
$obj = [pscustomobject] @{ one = [pscustomobject] @{ two = 2 } }

$obj | ForEach-Object one.two
'---'
$obj | Where-Object one.two -eq 2
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
1
---

one     
---     
@{two=2}
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
---
```

That is, the nested member access results in `$null` output.

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on macOS 10.13.3
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
Windows PowerShell v5.1.15063.674 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
```

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

labels.description: general cmdlet issues
labels.name: WG-Cmdlets

title: Support property paths in cmdlets that accept property names (nested member access)

## PR Summary

This was originally found where $PSversionTable.PSVersion was broken, but the real problem is whenever a table header spans multiple rows due to limited width, the calculation was incorrect for ensuring
no trailing whitespace.

To do this correctly, we need to calculate the last column that has content and add empty strings for cells that are empty.  Also make sure to trim the trailing whitespace from the last column that has content for
a given row.

body:
As discussed in #6473, [specifically here](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/6473#issuecomment-375930843).
Related: #6501

This inconsistency should either be resolved or, if changing the behavior is deemed to risky, documented.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
(New-Item -Type File .hidden.txt).Attributes = 'Hidden'
# Now target the hidden file with a *literal* path
[bool] (Get-Item .hidden.txt)
[bool] (Get-ChildItem .hidden.txt)
Test-Path .hidden.txt
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
True
True
True
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
Get-Item : Could not find item .../.hidden.txt.  # error
False
Get-ChildItem : Could not find item .../.hidden.txt.  # error
False
True
```

That is, `Test-Path` found the file, but neither `Get-Item` nor `Get-ChildItem` did - they, unlike the other filesystem-provider cmdlets, require the use of `-Force` even with _literal_ paths.

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on macOS 10.13.3
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
Windows PowerShell v5.1.15063.674 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
```

body:
See also: #6494, which suggests simplify the mechanism for obtaining provider-specific help.

Steps to reproduce (run on Windows, with help files installed)
------------------

```powershell
# Try to obtain the filesystem-specific Get-Item help topic by passing a filesystem-provider
# path to -Path:
(Get-Help Get-Item -Path C:\).Synopsis
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
Gets files and folders.
```

The above is the synopsis of the filesystem-provider-specific `Get-Item` help topic, as expected.

Actual behavior:
---------------

```none
Gets the item at the specified location.
```

That is, the abstract, provider-independent help was returned.
It seems that the `-Path` argument is ignored altogether.

Note that _Windows PowerShell_  is _not_ affected by this bug.

A quirk that _is_ in Windows PowerShell may resurface when this is fixed for Core, and is it worth fixing too:

Specifying a _nonexistent_ path is quietly ignored.
(As stated, Core currently ignores _any_ path.)

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on macOS 10.13.3
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
```

title: Get-Help -Path doesn't select provider-specific help

body:
The current mechanism for obtaining help for a given cmdlet's provider-specific incarnation is obscure (and brittle, which is worth fixing itself):

E.g., in order to get the filesystem-provider's help topic for `Get-Content`, you must use the `-Path` parameter with _any_ path that is a _implies_ the provider, e.g.:, for the registry provider (Windows):

```powershell
Get-Help Get-Item -Path HKCU:
``` 

Note: This mechanism is currently broken in PowerShell Core - see #6495

A more direct way would be to support a `-Provider` parameter that accepts:
 * the name of a PS provider (or an object obtained with `Get-PSProvider`)
 *  additionally, `None` to specifically request the abstract, provider-independent help topic.

Note: 

* _By default_, the provider that underlies the _current location_ is targeted, which is why being able to specify `None` to explicitly is important so as to request the _abstract_ topic.

* With the current `-Path` mechanism, the _documented_ approach is to use `-Path $null`, but that doesn't currently work - see #3949. (The workaround is to use a dummy drive name that doesn't exist; e.g., `Get-Help Get-Item -Path NoSuchDrive:`)


Wishful thinking
------------------

```powershell
# Get the FileSystem-provider-specific Get-Content help topic
Get-Help -Provider FileSystem Get-Content

# Get the generic Get-Content help topic
Get-Help -Provider None Get-Content
```


Environment data
----------------

Written as of:

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2
```

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

labels.description: help infrastructure and formatting of help
labels.name: WG-Interactive-HelpSystem

title: Add a -Provider parameter to Get-Help to better support provider-specific help

body:
`cmd.exe` shows the target paths of symlinks by default when you use `dir`; e.g., assuming a directory with directory symlink `tf.l`, file symlink `tl.txt`, and (directory) junction `tmp.j`, `dir` will show:

```none
 Directory of C:\Users\jdoe\foo

03/23/2018  04:50 PM    <SYMLINKD>     tf.l [tf]
03/23/2018  04:49 PM    <SYMLINK>      tl.txt [t.txt]
04/06/2017  02:07 PM    <JUNCTION>     tmp.j [\??\C:\tmp]
```

By contrast, PowerShell:

* doesn't show the target pathin its default output
* doesn't show the _type_ of link only `l` in the `Mode` property indicates that it is a link _in the abstract_ - though that may well be good enough

Given the importance of symlinks in the Unix world and their increasing importance on Windows, it would be convenient to include the symlink target paths:

Desired behavior
------------------

```powershell
# Emulated with the following command
#    Get-ChildItem | Select-Object Mode, LastWriteTime, Length, Name, Target | Format-Table
# Should be implemented analogously for Get-Item.
PS> Get-ChildItem

Mode   LastWriteTime        Length Name   Target  
----   -------------        ------ ----   ------  
d----l 3/23/2018 4:50:06 PM        tf.l   {tf}    
d----l 4/6/2017 2:07:17 PM         tmp.j  {C:\tmp}
-a---l 3/23/2018 4:49:21 PM 0      tl.txt {t.txt} 
```


Environment data
----------------

Written as of:

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2
```

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

labels.description: The issue is fixed.
labels.name: Resolution-Fixed

title: Add symlink target information to the default output format of Get-ChildItem / Get-Item

body:
### Setup

a.ps1

```ps1
&".\b.ps1" @args
```

b.ps1

```ps1
Param
(
    [Switch]
    $p1,
    [Switch]
    $p2,
    [String]
    $p3,
    [int]
    $p4
)

echo "p1: $p1"
echo "p2: $p2"
echo "p3: $p3"
echo "p4: $p4"
```

### Execution

  Invoke b.ps1 directly:

```ps1
.\b.ps1 -p1:$true -p2:$true

p1: True
p2: True
p3:
p4: 0
```

 Invoke through a.ps1:

```ps1
.\a.ps1 -p1:$true -p2:$true

p1: True
p2: True
p3: True
p4: 1
```

 Invoke through a.ps1 removing `:$true`:

```ps1
.\b.ps1 -p1 -p2

p1: True
p2: True
p3:
p4: 0
```


@SteveL-MSFT, this is our production code and i have reduced and anonymize it to demonstrate the problem. External party (Visual Studio in our case) calls `a.ps1` with `-p1:$true`, so we don't control that part. The only viable solution is to move code from b.ps1 to a.ps1. In our case, that means a lots of duplicate code.

is this a bug with PowerShell argument parsing, splatting or parameter binding? Please share if there is a workaround that can be made in a.ps1 or b.ps2 without raising our expectation from the caller.

labels.description: The issue is a duplicate.
labels.name: Resolution-Duplicate

------------------
Logged in as user1, who doesn't have access to restrictedfolder, running pwsh:

> Test-Path \\\server\share\restrictedfolder
Returns False    <--- This is correct

Open cmd.exe as user2, who have access to restrictedfolder, and run:

> dir \\\server\share

Switch back to the pwsh window, still running as user1

> Test-Path \\\server\share\restrictedfolder
Returns True   <--- This is incorrect

Still in pwsh, run 
> dir \\\server\share
> Test-Path \\\server\share\restrictedfolder
Returns False    <--- This is now correct again

Test-Path Should return False the whole time

Test-Path returns True for user1 after user2, who has more permissions in the file system. has accessed the share

body:
* The primary purpose of this issue to highlight how the existing behavior may be surprising to newcomers (and even for seasoned users hard to remember and therefore predict in specific situations).

* Given that the behavior has been around since the beginning, changing it is probably not an option, but _documenting_ how the behavior may be surprising is worth doing; while _some_ aspects of the behavior can be inferred from [`about_Parsing`](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Docs/blob/staging/reference/6/Microsoft.PowerShell.Core/About/about_Parsing.md), the overall implications aren't clear.
  * @SteveL-MSFT: This issue subsumes #3217, which therefore no longer needs the `Documentation Needed` label.

* While this may ultimately become a [documentation-repo issue](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Docs/issues), I would first like to solicit some feedback as to what code changes, if any, should be considered, after all (there are edge cases), and as to whether my summary is accurate.

* While there may be good _technical_ reasons for these behaviors, the problem is that they may be unexpected, especially given the deviation from how `cmd.exe` and `bash` handle these scenarios.

* All surprising behaviors can be avoided with proper _quoting_ - which is also worth pointing out in the docs -  but the need to quote negates one of the convenient aspects of argument syntax. If at the end of the day you cannot remember whether a particular token _requires_ quoting, your choices are to resort to trial and error, or to quote _everything_, which is cumbersome.

Note: By **_compound command-line token_** I mean a **logically single token composed of the _following syntax constructs_ by _direct concatenation_**:
 
* barewords (unquoted strings without special meaning; e.g., `foo`)
* quoted strings (e.g.; `'bar'`, `"baz"`)
* variable references (`$foo`) and subexpressions (`$(...)`)

Examples:

* `bar${foo}` and `${foo}bar` and `$($foo)bar`
* `foo"bar"` and `"bar"foo`

**The surprising aspects are**:

### Asymmetry: Whether a quoted string or subexpression comes _first_ matters:

Placing the quoted string or subexpression _first_ results in *2* arguments:

```powershell
PS> Write-Output 'hi'there
hi
there

> Write-Output $($env:HOME)/Documents
/Users/jdoe
/Documents
```

Otherwise, a _single_ argument is passed, as expected:

```powershell
PS> Write-Output hi'there'
hithere

PS> Write-Output Documents:$($env:HOME)  # Note: just $env:HOME without $() is not affected.
Documents:/Users/jdoe
```

###  `.` following a leading quoted string is interpreted as [string] property access

```powershell
PS> Write-Output 'hi'.there
   # NO output, because an attempt is made to access property .there on the string instance
```

###  `.` as the initial char. followed by a quoted string results in *2* arguments

```powershell
PS> Write-Output .'hi'
.
hi
```

###  `-` as the initial char. in something that turns out _not_ to be a parameter name  results in *2* arguments with the presence of `:` or `.` 

See also: #6292 and #6360.

```powershell
PS> Write-Output -foo:bar
-foo:
bar

PS> Write-Output -ip=10.0.0.1
-ip=10
.0.0.1
```
###  `-` as the initial char. causes embedded variable references not to be expanded

See also: #4624.

```powershell
PS> Write-Output a$HOME
a/home/jdoe  # e.g.; $HOME was expanded, as expected

PS> Write-Output -a$HOME
-a$HOME  # !! $HOME was NOT expanded
```

Note that the problem only surfaces if the there's at least 1 literal char. following the `-` before the variable reference; for instance, in `-$HOME` the variable _is_ expanded.


Environment data
----------------

Written as of:

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2
```

body:
In the pipeline, `[System.Data.DataTable]` is still treated as a _collection_ that implicitly enumerates its `.Rows` collection - through a mechanism that is unclear to me, given that it in other contexts this is currently, though possibly only temporarily, disabled (see #6453).

Given that `[System.Data.DataTable]`:

* itself has no `.Count` property
* is not itself indexable

the behavior with member enumeration - use of `.Count` and indexing - is not as expected:

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
# Create a sample data table with 2 rows.
1..2 | % { $dt = [Data.DataTable]::new("test") } { $dt.Rows.Add($dt.NewRow()) }

# If we assume that [DataTable] is a collection, this should be equal to $dt.Rows.Count, i.e., 2
$dt.Count

# If we assume that [DataTable] is an indexable collection, this should return the
# type name of the 2nd row, $dt.Rows[1], i.e., 'DataRow'
$dt[1].GetType().Name
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
2
DataRow
```

Note: If [DataTable] itself is NOT conceived of as a collection, the expected behavior would be (standard member enumeration):

```none
1  # a single [DataTable] instance
You cannot call a method on a null-valued expression.  # Error, because index 1 doesn't exist.
...
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
1  # post-#5756 only: member enumeration was applied to the items of .Row
1  # ditto
You cannot call a method on a null-valued expression.  # Error, index 1 was applied to $dt itself, not the .Rows collection
...
```

Note: `$dt.Count` returning `1, 1` is only seen with @iSazonov's #5756 PR in effect, which has not been released yet as of PowerShell Core v6.0.2; without it, `$null` is output, because the row objects lack the implicit `.Count` property.

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on macOS 10.13.3
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
Windows PowerShell v5.1.15063.674 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
```

Anyway, I was reading through [the third party license list](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/license_thirdparty_proprietary.txt) and taking deep breaths. I suppose that every PowerShell host must now redistribute the entire license file, right? I'm not exactly looking for a lawyer's opinion -- but it seems like this should be mentioned as a reminder in any documentation created about hosting PowerShell Core, because it's a major change from hosting Windows PowerShell.

As a side note:

Someone pointed out that there's [a _lot_ of libraries listed](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/license_thirdparty_proprietary.txt#L160-L414) as being under the 

```
MICROSOFT SOFTWARE LICENSE TERMS
MICROSOFT .NET LIBRARY
```

Which is, you know ... the old .NET license which is a bit confusing about redistribution.

I should point out that [this section](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/license_thirdparty_proprietary.txt#L466-L474) in particular is being [decried](https://listas.trisquel.info/pipermail/trisquel-users/2017-May/077549.html) online as non-free:

body:
Note: 
* The behavior described below has been in place since [member enumeration](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/powershell/2012/06/13/new-v3-language-features/) was introduced in v3 and only affects _array-valued_ properties.
* The behavior may well be by design, but given that it can be surprising, it may need to be _documented_.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
# Create an object whose .prop value is an array of hashtables, only one of 
# which as a .subProp entry whose value is a single-element array, then
# access .subProp via member enumeration.
$obj=[pscustomobject] @{ prop = @{foo='foo'}, @{subProp=,1}}; ($obj.prop.subProp).GetType().Name

# Create two 2-element arrays and let member enumeration collect them.
$obj=[pscustomobject] @{prop = @{subProp=1,2}, @{subProp=3,4}}; $obj.prop.subProp.Count
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
Int32
4
```

The single-element array was _unwrapped_.
The two 2-element arrays were _concatenated_ (rather than collected as-is in a 2-element array).


Alternative behavior
-----------------

One _could_ expect the following behavior, and contrasting it with the actual behavior is worth documenting:

```none
Object[]
2
```

The value of the properties could have been passed through, just as with _direct_ property access (e.g., `$obj.prop[-1].subProp`):

* In the first case: `, 1` may be expected, but `1` is returned.
  * Note that it's fine not to wrap `, 1` in an _outer_ array if only _one_ collection element's property value is found, because that is consistent with pipeline behavior.
* In the second case: `(1, 2), (3, 4)` may be expected, but `1, 2, 3, 4` is returned (the equivalent of `(1, 2) + (3, 4)`)

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on macOS 10.13.3
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
PowerShell Core v6.0.2 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
Windows PowerShell v5.1.15063.674 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
```

```csharp
protected override void ProcessRecord()

}
```

I'm not sure which behavior is better, but I expected 5.1 and 6.0 to behave the same in this respect.  If this change is deliberate I would like to understand why.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
$r = [System.Collections.ObjectModel.Collection[psobject]]{Write-Output $null -NoEnumerate}.Invoke()
$r.item(0).GetType()
```

Behavior in PowerShell 5.1
-----------------

```none
You cannot call a method on a null-valued expression.
At C:\Users\un1\Desktop\test.ps1:2 char:1
+ $r[0].GetType()
```

Ok! Heard me out.  While I was playing around with PowerShell Studio to create a form to display results coming from $PSversionTable in PSCore6 psobjects exported to clixml to then import to a psobject in Windows PowerShell.  

I found out the Import-CliXml will error out in Windows PowerShell with the following message:
```
Import-Clixml : SemanticVersion XML tag is not recognized. Line 81, position 8.
At line:1 char:10
+ $psobj = Import-Clixml -Path c:\Temp\pwshobject602.xml;
+          ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [Import-Clixml], XmlException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : System.Xml.XmlException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ImportClixmlCommand
```
Of course, this is not a Windows PowerShell issue as the workaround below works.

WorkAround
-----------------
Via code I had to fix the xml tag;
```
:
 $line.Replace('SemanticVersion', 'Version');
:
```
![psverxml_012018-03-21_11-17-46](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/37719350-32476eec-2cfb-11e8-8f3a-2ec4929ec865.png)


After fixing the xml tag then my application works. This only happens with the $PSVersionTable.

![pss2018_pwshcore_win01_2018-03-21_10-53-04](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/37719083-9a2d68f0-2cfa-11e8-9267-8b3f6ec9485e.jpg)


Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
## - Execute in PSCore 6.0.2:
(Get-Variable PSVersionTable).value.GetEnumerator()| Export-Clixml -Path c:\Temp\pwshobject602.xml;

## - Execute in Windows PowerShell:
$psobj = Import-Clixml  -Path c:\Temp\pwshobject602.xml;
Import-Clixml : SemanticVersion XML tag is not recognized. Line 81, position 8.
At line:1 char:10
+ $psobj = Import-Clixml -Path c:\Temp\pwshobject602.xml;
+          ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [Import-Clixml], XmlException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : System.Xml.XmlException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ImportClixmlCommand

```

Expected behavior
-----------------
To import the CliXml to a PSobject without any error.

Actual behavior
---------------
Error: "Import-Clixml : SemanticVersion XML tag is not recognized. Line 81, position 8."

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
## - PSCore6:
PS [156] > $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.2
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17127

PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

```

body:
## PR Summary

* Fixes #5964
* Adds `-Resume` switch to `Invoke-WebRequest` and `Invoke-RestMethod`
* `-Resume` requires `-OutFile`
* Enables ability to resume downloading a partially or incompletely downloaded file. 
* File Size is the only indicator of local and remote file parity.
* If the local file is smaller than the remote file and the remote endpoint supports resume, the local file will be appended with the remaining bytes.
* If the local file is larger than the remote file, the local file will be overwritten
* If the remote server does not support resume, the local file will be over written
* If the local file is the same size as the remote file, the remote endpoint will return a `416` status code. This response is special-cased as a success in this instance. The local file remains untouched and it is assumed the file was already successfully downloaded previously.
* If the local file does not exist it will be created and the entire remote file will be requested.

* Added tests for all code new code paths (I'm pretty sure anyway)
* Added `/Resume` Controller to WebListener
* Documented `/Resume` Controller
* Updated `.spelling` to reflect terms in WebListener docs

Note: I had to change the we `GetResponse()` tracks the current URI as we now have 3 places where the call is taking place. I don't foresee this causing any regressions. This area needs some refactoring. especially if we want to implement a retry mechanism.

body:
Quote Jason's comment at https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/6434/files/5b5be3122971552d2ce208858ac84868954b841c#r175933192

I'd suggest removing my ugly hack of using LINQ expression trees in `SaveError` and related helper methods, and replace with `nameof(ParserStrings.MissingEndCurlyBrace)`.

When that code was written, `nameof` was not in C#, so the ugly and inefficient code was used because:
* It ensured no typos in the `FullyQualifiedErrorId`.
* It was easy to search for all references to an error message via the property.
* Performance was not deemed important because they were errors.

Performance might matter more than I originally assumed given editor scenarios - and given the `nameof` language feature, it's reasonable (but annoying and a little verbose) to change error reporting to look more like:

```C#
ReportIncompleteInput(lCurly.Extent, rCurly.Extent,
    ParserStrings.MissingEndCurlyBrace, nameof(ParserStrings.MissingEndCurlyBrace));
```

In other words, pass the error text **and** the error id.

Alternatively you could just pass the error id and use reflection of some sort to load the error string, but that would not be good for performance.

labels.description: The issue is fixed.
labels.name: Resolution-Fixed
